#Text=flexible services for automating management of the identity life cycle.
#Text=ForgeRock Identity Platform™ serves as the basis for
#Text=our simple and comprehensive Identity and Access Management solution.
#Text=We help our customers deepen their relationships with their customers,
#Text=and improve the productivity and connectivity of their employees and partners.
#Text=For more information about ForgeRock and about the platform, see https://www.forgerock.com.
#Text=This guide shows you how to install ForgeRock Identity Management services for
#Text=evaluation or test installation, read the Release Notes before you get started.
#Text=This guide is written for anyone installing ForgeRock Identity Management software
#Text=to manage identities, and to ensure compliance with identity management
#Text=It covers the install and removal (uninstall) procedures that you
#Text=It aims to provide you with at
#Text=least some idea of what happens behind the scenes when you perform the steps.
#Text=You do not need a complete understanding of ForgeRock Identity Management
#Text=software to learn something from this guide, though a background in identity
#Text=management and maintaining web application software can help.
#Text=some background in managing services on your operating systems and in your
#Text=You can nevertheless get started with this guide, and
#Text=then learn more as you go along.
#Text=If you have a previous version of ForgeRock Identity Management software installed,
#Text=offers a large and increasing number of up-to-date, practical articles
#Text=that help you deploy and manage ForgeRock software.
#Text=While many articles are visible to community members,
#Text=ForgeRock customers have access to much more,
#Text=including advanced information for customers using ForgeRock software
#Text=ForgeRock product documentation, such as this document,
#Text=aims to be technically accurate and complete
#Text=It is visible to everyone and covers all product features
#Text=and examples of how to use them.
#Text=has links to source code for ForgeRock open source software,
#Text=as well as links to the ForgeRock forums and technical blogs.
#Text=raise a support ticket instead of using the forums.
#Text=ForgeRock support professionals will get in touch to help you.

#Text=ForgeRock Identity Management provides RESTful access to users in its repository.
#Text=To access the repository over REST, you can use a browser-based REST
#Text=client, such as the Simple REST Client for Chrome, or
#Text=command-line utility that is included with most operating systems.
#Text=IDM is accessible over the regular and secure HTTP ports of the
#Text=in this documentation set use the regular HTTP port, to avoid you having to

#Text=To run curl over the secure port, 8443, you must either

#Text=Database Access Rights For a JDBC Repository
#Text=In general, IDM requires minimal access rights to the JDBC
#Text=required, and suggests a strategy for restricting database access in your
#Text=The JDBC repository used by IDM requires only one
#Text=relevant user - the service account that is used to
#Text=Generally, the details of this account are configured in
#Text=and password for this account are openidm and
#Text=All other users are created by the
#Text=The openidm user account must have SELECT, UPDATE,
#Text=INSERT, and DELETE permissions on all the openidm tables that are created by
#Text=this script, by the scripts that create the tables specific to the Activiti
#Text=workflow engine, and by the script that sets up the audit tables if you are
#Text=Configuring Case Insensitivity For a JDBC Repository
#Text=A DS repository is case-insensitive by default.
#Text=cause issues if queries expect results to be returned, regardless of case.
#Text=For example, with the default configuration of a MySQL database, a search for
#Text=an email address of scarter@example.com might return a
#Text=results, while a search for scarter@EXAMPLE.COM might
#Text=return an Unable to find account error.
#Text=If you need to support case-insensitive queries, you must configure a
#Text=case-insensitive collation in your JDBC repository, on the specific columns
#Text=For example, for a generic managed object mapping in MySQL or MariaDB, change
#Text=change case-sensitivity for all the properties of a specific object, specify
#Text=a different table for the propertiesTable entry in your
#Text=repo.jdbc.json for that object, and adjust the collation
#Text=To change case-sensitivity only for certain properties of an
#Text=For a PostgreSQL repository, use an explicit table structure if you require
#Text=Managing case-insensitivity at scale with generic tables
#Text=explicit object mappings, see "Generic and Explicit Mappings With a JDBC Repository" in the Integrator's Guide.
